page.title: 02GAZETTEER (Continued)
page.content: amounting to two hides. With the now lost hamlet of Hinton it formed part of the land held by the King. The only other part of the area mentioned in the original survey is Gossington with its four hides which also formed part of "Terra Regis". The hamlet of Gossington still exists in name although there are only a few dwellings and a garage there now. There can be little doubt that the two "claims to fame" for the area are Sir Peter Scott's Wildfowl Trust just outside Slimbridge and the fact that William Tyndale, translator of the Bible, came from Slimbridge. The villages are very closely linked as many of the usual village facilities - Church, Hall, school etc. - are shared. As in almost all cases these are now found in Slimbridge this means that the village of Cambridge
